topic.title: ZeroNet update broke things for me too
topic.body:
I grabbed a fresh copy of py3 ZeroNet, set it up, then copied my data folder into it. It seems smoother but some zites don't work any more.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/ ZeroUp gives me a popup: Internal error: AttributeError: 'SiteStorage' object has no attribute 'piecefields'
UiWebsocket.py line 85 > UiWebsocket.py line 232 > OptionalManager/UiWebsocketPlugin.py line 168 > OptionalManager/UiWebsocketPlugin.py line 66

http://127.0.0.1:43110/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC/ Millchan Engine is a blank page

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/ Millchan is empty except an 'if this message doesn't go away try updating ZeroNet" message

Did I break it or did it break it?

topic.title: What do I do about the ZeroTalk space limit?
topic.body: I'm not convinced that nofish is real but it says to beg for an increase. Other than that am I supposed to hunt and prune old posts?

1543928148_1E5pgBaKNzFU9Loeg7eDGrSkXqJAq.body:
Lovely. I'm sure they'll implement it with a flawless, infallible automated system like YouTube has :) :)

We really ought to be moving things over to distributing networks like ZeroNet and Freenet, where one careless flick of a corporate wrist won't as easily demolish large amounts of content unrelated to the suggested intent. Heavy centralization makes it easy for the likes of Apple to push us all around even if we have nothing to do with them ourselves. Who can bully networks like ZeroNet? Their design intentionally precludes this. In addition, the burden of content distribution being shared enables the existence of sites made by people who otherwise can't reliably host them.

Not that porn in general is the most important thing around. I just think banning an otherwise acceptable category of content out of plain laziness(??) is ridiculous and we can easily get ahead of these corporate games by moving to systems less easily disrupted: let's all share where they can't stop us.

...Oh, and Tumblr of all things banning porn? Do they have anything else there? Did Tumblr just ban Tumblr from Tumblr? Maybe that was a bad idea.

> [xianc78](#comment_28_141zS75MupoDVjN4p7ivG9pXUXjAm9jLBQ): Yes, but I don't think most Tumblr users would be tech-savvy enough to use them and I bet once they realize that ZeroNet is uncensored, they will call us an "alt-right platform" or something like that.

I like to think it wouldn't be excessively difficult for people to figure out how to download and run (the daemon for) the friendliest dark/alt/whatever net around and navigate to a known URL. I hope not, anyway. I don't really know Tumblr but "run this and paste 127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTumbl.bit into your browser" seems easy enough to me.

Secondly, it will have to be understood that ZeroNet is a network, not a platform. There are platforms for alt-right content on the clearnet so there presumably are platforms for alt-right content here as well. The point is for people to create platforms serving their communities that coexist on the network with platforms serving others just the same as on the clearnet but without being fully at some company's mercy, not to mention typically being mined for profit as well.

I guess my point is that I see moving to these sorts of networks as a necessity. There will be some growing pains but those are necessary for the networks in general as well as for any particular one playing host to a freshly displaced community. People need communities and we simply can't depend on corporations to host them, especially outside of the most banal mainstream sorts of content. Something's got to give!

Besides, I'm sure the freeze peach and alt-right types will be welcoming enough to those with disparate opinions who just need a place to stay :) :)
Worst case, different groups could technically form new networks. AltRightNet, LeftNet, JustABunchOfPornNet (the big one, naturally), whatever. I don't know if anyone would consider that optimal but I consider even that an improvement over erasing communities dozens or hundreds at a time just because some company finds they're no longer convenient to have around. If nothing else it may keep those communities alive until a more suitable solution is found.

1544323909_18XCUzg18zdzeVbSNrvqRQ9cLn8Uq.body:
General suggestion not specific to this post:

Where possible content referenced here should be hosted or mirrored somewhere within ZeroNet.This helps keep content alive even if something happens to its clearnet hosting and may confer some protection against tracking.

Note that tracking can still be done but it may require additional effort to track through ZeroNet as opposed to directly telling Google or anyone else what people are looking at.

The same goes for any other network of the sort.

1544703954_1GHXQ3vMtadfHFjTwS3roqYe8LUsy.body:
Just rambling/listing a few things off the top of my head. ZeroNet has/is/does:
-No filter (JavaScript everywhere running coin miners or what have you, no warnings about downloading potentially malicious files)
-People (this thread has seen about as much content in minutes as Freenet seems to see daily :P)
-Quite possibly doesn't give a useful damn about your security or anonymity (partly the filter thing, partly that it doesn't seem to* reeeeally want to use Tor 100% unless(?) you're extra careful, etc.) *There's a setting for using Tor for peer connections and then another sneaking around down below for proxying tracker connections through it. Is this in addition? Does "Tor always" actually mean that or must both be set? Dunno. I say "Don't trust ZeroNet unless you really know what you're doing." I don't think most people around here do.
-Very much more user-friendly (ZeroHello is like "Hi, come play with ZeroNet :)" versus Freenet's list of years-old... stuff, as an example. Also allowing JavaScript enables some more comfortable/typical interaction with zites and there are working analogues to familiar clearnet sites)
-Less... crusty old (Freenet and the software it's built on are aging and not at all like wine)
-Doing things at all is much more practical (ZeroNet's Twitter thing (or whatever ZeroMe is) is two clicks from posting while Freenet's Sone requires working out how to install and set up two plugins and then waiting for potentially days or weeks to discover any of the arguably 'active' users on it. Accessing the network's forum involves downloading and running a separate piece of software and accessing that using its own server.)
-Actually works more (remember that bit about plugins? Sone isn't installed by default because of... problems. I don't remember what the story with FMS (forum) is.)
-It seems much faster, possibly due to having a (probably) larger user base.

Freenet seems to have fewer people with their heads lodged up their backsides, though. Of course, as far as I can tell there are only about five people communicating on it at all so maybe that isn't saying so much :D
Another thread with some relevant bits: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1543348094_16VrCKQQiVZpJ6S5xJASR8LCFLv24M5bfn/I+discovered+Zeronet+a+few+years+ago+but+immediately+abandoned+it+due+to+the+massive+neglect+of+user+security+Have+things+changed

Freenet does distribute files across the network. https://freenetproject.org/pages/documentation.html#content There's no need to stay online once your content is on other peers who are. As for changing freesites, they're let's say 'strongly recommended' to be quite small and mostly text-based. One could claim that the purposes of zites and freesites are actually quite different.

1544937960_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
Improving ease of getting to content and how much content is worth seeing are priorities. Sure, add lots of "IP" people want to see. Give people reasons to be here and while they're here they will probably at least have some things to say. Some guidance with regard to which sites for any specific use are any good (and still working) would also be useful. One example: we have KopyKate (two of them), YouTube (the ZeroNet one), IFS, and probably another dozen or so similar zites. Why? Tell that to every new user. Actually, tell that to me too. Why do we have so many sites all doing the same thing for every 'thing' there is to do? Which ones work and are popular enough to work well? Which ones have content I want? Anyone joining ZeroNet right now has to work their way through a mess of half-populated redundant zites, missing but listed content, and countless indices with little or no indication of zite quality or freshness. Ouch.

A very important issue letting people know this thing exists at all. Tell people about it and why they want to be here on a larger scale than whispers and posts where only people who already know will see them. Throw lots of people at the problem and it will probably get better, right? Then we bring back the ones who left because it's a mess and everything is good.

Actually this seems to all apply to othernets in general. It's all very messy and ad-hoc, which is partly useful but makes it difficult to really expect people to join up unless they specifically enjoy digging around in mostly very old material looking for anything interesting. There's a lot of information but it's mostly wrong, old, confusing, or just spread all over the place and hard to find, collect, and comprehend.

TL;DR: Spread the word much more generally and deal with the messiness.

> [blurhy](#comment_209_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): no,it's easy

This is most of the reason for ZeroNet. Once something is on the network it's shared by everyone who wants it. You don't need 10Mbps upload speed if you've got 10 people sharing 1 each.

1552916412_1GDzVsFoYamHqWcYBcuvVWFCAt3Y5.body:
> [redlibertyreal](#comment_11_1D6UcmziWg55aXV6TnCksXpjsFJ4gDK6Kw): Of course it uses IP to connect to the network, but inside the network router lease-sets (if memory serves me) are used (essentially just a pair of public keys) so you don't really know the IP of a person you are connecting to 2 hops out (average connection to an "eepsite" is 13 hops I believe), and 13 separate hops back. Their official website at https://geti2p.net/ has AMAZING documentation, I can read it for hours. I love I2P, I host my own hidden services with them, but I wouldn't say it's perfect. It doesn't have the same academic research, funding, and pen testing as the Tor project does to back up its claims (certainly not I2P's fault) so I wouldn't rely on it for STRONG anonymity. Theoretically it's better than Tor for darknets, but in practice who is to say? I2P though is by far my favorite "darknet". I steer clear of far too many things on ZeroNet because it is so decentralized, using pretty much only the main services (like ZeroTalk, ZeroMe, etc.). The pornography blacklist is a good start, but I don't think it goes far enough. I2P is decentralized, yes, but its services are centralized where they need to be, and every centralized service can be mirrored and replaced if you needed to go to the effort in a worst-case scenario. You have B32 addresses (the hostname, essentially super long public keys) and you can get a domain name free of charge to associate with the "real" address from people who distribute them (identiguy, meeh, zzz, etc.) Most of the domain name providers won't give you an address if you are doing bad things, and you yourself specify what DNS services your router will use. Bad people who reflect badly on the network and give it a bad rep are actively discouraged from participating. You can still do what you like, no one will stop you, but I2P is what I would consider an "ethical darknet", inspired by the same principles and ideas of the developers of other darknets. It's run by good people, the overwhelming majority of its users are good people. They are basically striving to avoid the mistakes made by the architectures by which information flows, to avoid the mistakes of Freenet, ZeroNet, and the culture of criminality that enveloped around Tor. It's unique in that regard. If you want to do bad stuff on I2P (other than piracy lol) I say "fuck off". But if you genuinely like the technology, are interested in the ideas and philosophy behind it, or want a safe place to host a decent anonymous website you'd feel comfortable showing your Grandma, I say to you, welcome!

Well, that wall of mess has some issues...

You like to be protected from what people don't want you to see? Your choice, I guess, but can we call it what it is? You've started out from a position of letting other people decide what you should be interacting with. Even if the ones doing it now are trustworthy I find this idea very strange in the context of darknets. 
Actually, does your/my grandmother want to see even all of what's on the clearnet? I guess you want more restrictions on darknet content than elsewhere.

It sounds like you want a whitelist to determine what's reachable or at least easy to get to? Who determines this? Who determines this after they're gone? And them? Is it really the case that the powers that be will never be trusted beyond their worthiness? 

When an eepsite goes offline, who can archive or mirror it? Sounds like dark magic to me.

Okay, I've left this for ages and don't want to try reading that wall again so I'll stop here. I'm a fan of I2P, actually, and quite like its design. Just this post kinda creeps me out. What's the point in a darknet where somebody gets to tell you what you're allowed to see and say. Normally I don't give a damn about peach temperature but it seems to me deliberate control systems will push whatever politics they're put to. We should be building things to last and serve everyone, not to serve the interests of one or a few. You seem to think "piracy lol" is fine, but others disagree. Maybe they live by necessity (their nation outlaws their religion, maybe?) some "criminality" or "bad stuff" you don't but have good reason to. Oh well for them? Liberty enough for your grandmother, I guess.

Neither other people nor (especially not!) the underlying technology should have anything to say about what's allowed or even equal on a darknet. Saying and sharing things others don't want us to is the entire point, isn't it? If not then why not use more active services like Facebook or such? More people, more content, more activity, and everything they dislike is bannable!

1566642594_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: It's kinda funny-odd to watch new infrastructure just pop up :D

I'd like to know more about plugins. Where should I look? I see much mention of installing them and apparently there should be a /Plugins I can access to see which I have and what they're up to but this doesn't seem to be the case.

> [gitcenter](#comment_721_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): If you're asking whether I'm going to ban something -- no I'm not, unless there is much spam.

I could see automated mass registration being a problem. We did just take an influx of trolls and other trash.

> [gitcenter](#comment_723_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): You must be using an old ZeroNet version. Please update (the latest is v0.7.0, rev notrememberwhatexactly).

ZeroHello says it's up to date but I can update to a development version?

> [gitcenter](#comment_725_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): That's why there's file limit. The domains are checked every 5 seconds. You can put about 10 domains at a moment. So you get about 120 domains per minute. That's a lot (but not very a lot), but I hope I'll notice that something is wrong and stop spamming.

Alright, seems reasonable enough.

> [kaffie](#comment_1078_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): This experience has taught me one thing: if a dns is first come first serve, it's always going to die by squatters.

Sounds like an opportunity for some problem solving! Anyone have ideas on this? GNUnet has addresses based on who you learned them from but I feel like that wouldn't go over well here.

> [kaffie](#comment_1079_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): In practice we should have a list where people submit a domain+address, start the vote count at zero (or 1 for the submitter), and then allow people to vote up +1 for domain suggestions. Then just use the top-voted address for the domain. That way it's not first come first serve, but rather what most people think the domain should point to. If a site dies or people find a better use for the domain, it could switch via democratic vote.

That would be good if there were a way to ensure that people are voting and that the users voting are people. Of course it could be "surprising" to people who use relatively unknown zites if most people don't know what is expected to be there (and some other people decide to take the domains from them).

> [blurhy](#comment_340_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): could you join https://t.me/ipzeronet telegram discussion

This Telegram stuff is creeping me out.

> [gitcenter](#comment_763_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): .it used to be the default TLD. After this switch, .yo became the default one. Most sites used .it and didn't use domain hacks, so I figured out that replacing .it with .yo would work good enough. [...]

But then it's about yu, not me :( Nor kaffie. Hey, you could make a .kaffie TLD! :D Better than .yo and .yu, I think.
Maybe we can tell ICANN to give up the domains we want.
(.kaffie would be only for kaffie and any selected kaffienated friends, of course)

I don't understand what's going on with clearnet here. Does that have something to do with anything other than domain name collisions?

> [gitcenter](#comment_766_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): This is the very reason. There were many suggestions to support clearnet DNS for ZeroNet addresses, so ZeroNet has to be compatible with Clearnet. If there was search.it in Clearnet DNSes and search.it in Name.YO, what address should be used?

Okay, I assumed there was something else and people were just using a plugin or such to map domains to ZeroNet addresses. Why use clearnet DNS for ZeroNet addresses?

> [gitcenter](#comment_773_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Because, uh, why not? We're not trying to burn WWW and replace it with ZeroNet; we're trying to integrate ZeroNet to the Internet and make it the Web 3.0.

That makes a lot more sense than using clearnet DNS to get addresses not accessible from the clearnet :P I wasn't aware there was a plan or intent for that.

1566671185_1GFU4qAMTFnQJ7W7r98Zj2xJWq1ev.body:
Interesting. I'm getting a not found at that CSL link, found a copy at https://eunichx.us/c/csl-2019-05-07.txt
I see some potential issues with your 5F, though. Definition ambiguity risks enormous gaps for someone (especially someone with a lot of lawyer power) to equivocate about what "category of purposes" applies or how "far as can be permitted by circumstances."

5F5 confuses me a little. I think it's meant to be "for anything else, it's up to specific agreements?" I'm not entirely sure what that means just yet. It may take some time to process this (rather un-short :P) document :3

> [kaffie](#comment_1089_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): My opposition to the licensed FOSS model was always the centralization and reliance on copyright. But reading your post here it seems there's even another worry: having this apply to "malicious" software. You touched a bit upon this in terms of a malicious government, but there are malicious people as well. And tracking isn't the only malicious software use case. [...]

I think there's significant benefit to pushing or coercing people into sharing. It seems like a lot of people are very selfish or ashamed of their code and will base their decision more on that than on ethics, mortality, the common good, etc.

Your post reminds me of some criticisms of the PPL (http://wiki.p2pfoundation.net/Peer_Production_License#Why_it_is_dangerous_to_differentiate_between_.22good.22_and_.22bad.22_users_.28Ralf_Schlatterbeck.29) regarding left/farleft licenses turned into weapons against their intent. I'm pretty sleepy, though, so I'll have to do more reading and pondering later.

1566679861_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: Everyone gets to pick features and you have to implement them?! That's an interesting way to build things :P

> I don't get the obsession with making reddit clones. I think the reddit format sucks for having meaningful conversations. [...]

I disagree with most of this. Do all conversations have to take place on Reddit? The OP already mentions connecting with other services.
What's the difference between a post with 10 points vs. a post with 5 points, and a post with 5 points (10 minus the 5 from the opposing view) vs. a post with -5? It's pure popularity producing your "correct answer" either way. The first way pretends every post has merit (which isn't true) while the latter lets you know immediately what kind of place you've encountered.
Why not use all of the above, since we have the unlimited wishlist to work with here? Show positive and negative votes and allow sorting and filtering by them.

I want it!
Too bad it has to be made first and getting people to use it may be easier said than done.

> [nicehat](#comment_13_1LPjWhB47YZwaWoSQH1d2tnj2E3JnMU2cw): I have the same issue. Any packages in particular?

It would complain about 'quoted' modules not being available so I used `pip3 search ??` trying to find what provides that. I think this included merkletools, bitcoin, bencode3 or bencode-python3, and maybe other stuff. I may have also used my local package manager to install some other things. Sorry I didn't keep a record of what I did.

The error messages were at the top of the console output from `python3 zeronet.py` so if you have those you may be able to work out what to do from those or ask about specific messages.
